 I think the main purpose of the commandments (and there are hundreds of them throughout exodus, leviticus and deuteronomy) was to keep the population under the soveriegn authority of the religious leaders at the time, then later under the kings that stuck to the commandment formula. And yes, the basic commandments cover stuff to stop people from harming others, but "do unto others as you'd have done unto you" wasn't what the religious law was all about. It was about power. 
 
 I agree with you that I think the law makers had noble intentions. They truly conceived that God was a being of order and rules and had a terrible wrath that could smite the heathen at any given time. They believed that their very survival (crop harvests, natural disasters, war conquests, etc) depended on God being in a good mood. So it was detrimental that everybody be on their best behavior, since one sinner in the midst could jeapordize the entire country. Also, I think that the lawmakers believed that God would ultimately reward them for obeying the law, and had noble reasons for encouraging others to do the same.

They were all considered abominations as far as the old testament law was concerned, and were shunned, kicked out of the city, or killed. There was zero tolerance for sin.
